zetabeta:

i think signal org should start planning to go another jurisdiction if something goes very bad, maybe canada.

Could the topic that I started on that a while back perhaps be relisted again? Because Signal being American is starting to become an issue for some people on the other side of the pond who are seeking to make themselves less reliant on American services and who are worried that Signal might be coerced into compliance with whatever bullying the current regime might come up with.

What is the reason for this, does anyone knows?
It wasn‚Äôt that long ago Musk sent that message ‚Äúuse Signal‚Äù. Why has he reneged? Must be something to do with politics.

posts.name: (he/him)
posts.cooked: Signal is a tool often used by whistleblowers, apparently including those reporting on the DOGE department.

I added a signal.me link in a post on X and in my bio just now and it worked. I know the context, but couldn‚Äôt this be linked to a sudden increase in spam (or messages detected as such) recently that contained links to Signal users or groups?

anon41607674:

What is the reason for this, does anyone knows?
It wasn‚Äôt that long ago Musk sent that message ‚Äúuse Signal‚Äù. Why has he reneged? Must be something to do with politics.

politics is not a only reason. x.com has some kind of encrypted direct messages feature, so signal is a competitor to x.com. if i recall correctly, x.com is closed source software, who knows what it does.

Very good, thank you for the comment, it was precisely this fear that prompted me to register here today.

And since yesterday, February 28, 2025, we can say here on the other side of the pond: We don‚Äôt trust this US government and we don‚Äôt trust the tech companies either, especially not those who now bow low to the ‚Äúnew.‚Äù And the question arises as to how long Signal can continue to protect itself from the clique‚Äôs grasp.

Or, in view of the disaster unfolding over there, which is taking place before the eyes of the world, is it better for us to turn our backs from as many US-American IT products as possible for our own safety? The replacement for Signal would be the product Threema. A commercial product, it has to be purchased, but no data is siphoned off and it is secure, and it is European.

Signal is designed in a way in which you don‚Äôt need to trust the server, so I wouldn‚Äôt worry too much about its geographical location. One issue I do see is that a malicious U.S. government could prevent Signal from operating its servers the U.S., but that would just force them to find alternatives.

If there are realistic concerns here I‚Äôm sure the Signal team are very aware of them.

Also, Threema doesn‚Äôt even have forward secrecy so it cannot be considered a Signal alternative: Threema: Three Strikes, You‚Äôre Out - Dhole Moments

link_counts.title: Threema: Three Strikes, You‚Äôre Out - Dhole Moments

posts.cooked: Thank you for the reply. As far as Signal is concerned, I find it reassuring for the time being. What remains worrying, however, is that anything is now possible with this administration, and it will be interesting to see how this will affect American IT products.
I think we should boycot X.

eaaac3fdfaff:

Also, Threema doesn‚Äôt even have forward secrecy so it cannot be considered a Signal alternative: Threema: Three Strikes, You‚Äôre Out - Dhole Moments

Well, the article is dated November 5, 2021‚Ä¶

In the meantime, however, Threema has (PFS) Perfect Forward Secrecy.
https://threema.ch/en/faq/perfect_forward_secrecy

Their website says: " Threema supports Perfect Forward Secrecy both on the transport layer and on the end-to-end layer. Technical information can be found in the Cryptography Whitepaper".

I use both Threema and Signal, with Signal being my clear favorite. This is especially noticeable in less powerful network environments.

So much for my experience.

posts.cooked: I‚Äôve had Threema for 8 years. I still have no contacts on it . I have around 30 on Signal.

Avitus:

I‚Äôve had Threema for 8 years. I still have no contacts on it

The reason might be that the one-time fee discourages many people from using Threema. But what is a one-time fee when you compare it to the server costs? Not to mention the developer costs too. And let‚Äôs be honest, how quickly has one spent money on a coffee?

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: Threema‚Äôs UI is ugly af anyway. I redownload it once every couple years to see if anyone‚Äôs using it.
I‚Äôve never heard of it, but their UI looks like WhatsApp from screens I see?

Avitus:

I‚Äôve had Threema for 8 years. I still have no contacts on it . I have around 30 on Signal.

I had considered Threema but chose to remain with Signal mainly due to the contact discovery feature. While a Threema user could include a phone number to facilitate discovery, it was optional. That is now the case with Signal. Even if many more people start to use Signal, if they choose to disallow discovery by phone number, then each one will need to somehow share that Signal is an option. For those who keep Whatsapp or whatever else they use for common communication, a very likely scenario would be that people are still communicating via Whatsapp, Viber, SMS, etc. even though they all have Signal.
